metadata.synopsis: Controversial comedian Lenny Bruce (Dustin Hoffman) begins his career telling bad jokes to bored audiences in the 1950s, but can't repress his desire to unleash edgier material. When he does, he begins a one-man campaign to break down social hypocrisy, and his groundbreaking stage act propels him to cult-hero status. When authorities ban Lenny's act for obscenity, he begins a downward spiral of drugs, sex and debt, aided by his bombshell wife, a stripper named Honey (Valerie Perrine).

A mess -- precisely because it is neither fact nor imaginative fiction. Fosse and Barry never figured out for themselves how this nothingy little comic grew into a heroic figure and, rightly or wrongly, a legend
Lenny the film is fragmented because Lenny the man didn't cohere. And Dustin Hoffman plays this incoherent man with insecure, manic glee.
Dustin Hoffman gives one of his best performances, and the choice to shoot the film in matted black and white is bold and beautiful.
Most damaging of all... is that the film lacks a coherent potnt of view.
Bob Fosse has recreated a perfect atmosphere for Lenny Bruce. [Full Review in Spanish]

Few films before Lenny are so ingeniously edited, and yet because the jumpy style has become so familiar in film and television, we no longer appreciate how innovative the approach of Fosse and his film editor, Alan Heim, was.
Dustin Hoffman, good as he is in the title role, is never quite permitted to put together an organic, three-dimensional character.
'Lenny' is a lousy movie about a comedian but it's a great film about a toxic marriage.

Valerie Perrine delivers a heartbreaking performance, one which earned her the Best Actress prize at Cannes as well as Best Supporting Actress awards from the New York Film Critics Circle and the National Board of Review.

As helmed by Fosse and interpreted by Dustin Hoffman, Lenny is too fragmented and episodic to illuminate the controversial comedian but it's a personal, prophetic film, offering insights into the real life and death of Bob Fosse as a filmmaker.
His performance may feel too Actors Studio at times, but he radiates his broad-spectrum intensity until Lenny becomes something of a Dustin Hoffman film festival in miniature.
Well done, but somehow lifeless biopic.
A bravura turn by Hoffman, plus Fosse's kinetic direction make this an unforgettable biography.
Dustin Hoffman succesfully transmits to screen some of the rage of Lenny Bruce, a hard role to digest and project.
A sturdy biopic with a fine Dustin Hoffman performance.
